Name: Session1_long
Title: Week 1: Part 2
Description: Please select the domain you'd like to work on today.

BeforeDomain.Name: Welcome Back!
BeforeDomain.Title: Welcome Back!
Description:
Welcome back to MindTrails! Let's get started with practicing flexible thinking. 

Today, you will: answer a few questions about your anxiety, complete 3 scenarios that challenge you to come up with thoughts, feelings, and behaviors, and wrap-up with a Quick Thinking exercise. 

Let's get started!

BeforeDomain.Name: Three Brief Questions
BeforeDomain.Title: Three Brief Questions
Description:
Thinking about the last 24 hours, how anxious have you felt? 

0 = Most calm I could imagine being. 

10 = Most anxious, panicked, or scared I could imagine being.

BeforeDomain.Name: Three Brief Questions
BeforeDomain.Title: Three Brief Questions
Description:
Thinking about the last 24 hours, how much were you able to change the way you thought about things when you wanted to feel better. 

An example might be: If you were feeling worried about an upcoming test, were you able to remind yourself that you studied a lot and were prepared? 

0 = Not at all - I wasn't able to think in different ways to feel better. 

10 = Completely - I was totally able to think in different ways to feel better.

OtherChoices: I didn't want\need to change my feelings

BeforeDomain.Name: Three Brief Questions
BeforeDomain.Title: Three Brief Questions
Description:
Thinking about the last 24 hours, how much did you try to stay away from or be less involved in situations that would make you anxious or scared? 

An example might be: If your teacher asked a question to the class and you knew the answer, do you not answer so you won't draw attention to yourself? 

0 = I tried to stay away from doing anything and everything that would make me anxious or scared. 

10 = If there was something that would make me anxious or scared, I pushed myself to do it anyway.

OtherChoices: Nothing happened that made me anxious

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description: In this exercise, please think of an UPCOMING situation that you expect will make you feel anxious, worried, or scared. Pick a situation that you worry might go badly, or that you expect will bring on feelings of anxiety (like racing heart, sweating). Any situation that will make you feel quite anxious or scared will work, as long as it is a situation that is likely to actually happen.

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description: Please describe the situation in a few words:

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description: Please imagine the situation as vividly as possible (i.e., so that it feels very real). Try to imagine you are actually in the situation. Play out the specific parts of the situation in your head. Try to imagine using all your senses while you think about this situation. Think about the things you would see, hear, and smell if you were really in that situation. Think about the kinds of things you would think or feel if you were actually there.

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description: Play this situation in your head for the next 20 seconds. The screen will change automatically after 20 seconds

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description:
How anxious did you feel (at the highest level of anxiety) as you completed the imagery task?  

0 = Absolutely no anxiety. 

10 = Totally anxious.

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description: How vividly did you imagine the situation?

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description: How likely is it that the situation or task will turn out well versus turn out badly?

Items: Very likely to turn out well
Somewhat likely to turn out well
Somewhat likely to turn out badly
Very likely to turn out badly

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description: If this situation did turn out badly, how well or badly would you be able to handle it?

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description:
On the next screen, you will be asked to write about a possible upcoming event in your life, or something that you are worried might happen. Before pressing NEXT, please think about a situation that might happen over the next week when you will feel anxious, scared, or worried. This can be a situation that makes you anxious a lot, or something that doesn't happen a lot. 

As you think of an event, try to really see yourself in the situation. Where are you? What day of the week is it? What time is it? Who is around you? What are you doing? How do you feel?  

After you come up with your situation, please press NEXT.  

Examples could include taking a test, talking to strangers, using social media, dealing with family or friends, or whatever makes you feel anxious.

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description: Please take a moment to write one or two sentences to describe the situation. Press next when you are ready to continue.

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description: For the next 30 seconds, please picture yourself in this situation. When you are finished, the screen will change automatically.

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description:
Now, take the next 90 seconds to think of as many different thoughts that you could have in the situation as you can. These thoughts can be negative or positive. Be as creative as possible with all of the different thoughts you could have while you're in the situation that makes you anxious, especially thoughts that would help you feel less anxious.  

Please type each of the thoughts in the box below. You can put each thought on a new line. 

The screen will change after 90 seconds.

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description: Great job! You predicted the future! Now, if your situation happens over the next week, you can have a lot of different thoughts come into your mind. Try to remember some of your thoughts that make you feel less anxious!

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description: Great job practicing flexible thinking today. Remember, try to use your new flexible thinking skills before your next training session!

Scenarios.Name: Long Scenarios
Scenarios.Title: Long Scenarios
Description:
Next, you're going to see a scenario that might make you anxious. As you read the short story, picture yourself in that situation. After you picture yourself in the situation, click "Next" and then you'll see examples of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that might happen in that situation. 

 Some of the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors will be helpful and some won't be.

Scenarios.Name: Long Scenarios
Scenarios.Title: Long Scenarios
Description:
The goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative. 

 After you see some thoughts, you'll be asked to write your own example of a helpful thought that you might have in that situation. You'll do the same thing for feelings and behaviors.

Scenarios.Name: Long Scenarios
Scenarios.Title: Long Scenarios
Description: Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.

Scenarios.Name: Scenario1
Scenarios.Title: Scenario 1
Description: Your English teacher calls on you to answer a question about the book you just read. You say your best answer and your peers are quiet.
Scenarios.Caption: Answering a question

Scenarios.Name: Scenario 1 Thoughts
Scenarios.Title: Scenario 1 Thoughts
Words: My answer was thoughtful.
It was nice to be able to share what I think about the book.
My classmates are judging my wrong answer.
My answer sounded dumb because I didn't understand the book, but no one will remember tomorrow.
If my English teacher didn't call on me, I wouldn't have made a fool of myself. I'll have a better answer next time.
Description:
Your English teacher calls on you to answer a question about the book you just read. You say your best answer and your peers are quiet.

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Scenarios.Name: Be creative!
Scenarios.Title: Be creative!
Description:
Now's your chance to be creative! What could you say to yourself to make you feel better in this situation?  

For the next 30 seconds, write as many different thoughts that you might have that would be helpful in this situation. You can use the thoughts that you saw a moment ago for inspiration, or can list things that you've told yourself in the past that have helped. 

What could you tell yourself in this situation that would help you feel less anxious or would help you handle your feelings of anxiety?

Scenarios.Name: Be creative!
Scenarios.Title: Be creative!
Description:
Your English teacher calls on you to answer a question about the book you just read. You say your best answer and your peers are quiet.

Thoughts in the moment:
Great job! Now you'll see some feelings.

Scenarios.Name: Scenario 1 Feelings
Scenarios.Title: Scenario 1 Feelings
Words: I'm glad my teacher gave me the opportunity to share my answer.
I'm satisfied with how I said my answer.
I was scared while answering
I'm disappointed in myself because I couldn't say what I wanted to say, but I think my teacher understood my point.
I was really anxious while I was answering, but was able to manage my feelings.
Description:
Your English teacher calls on you to answer a question about the book you just read. You say your best answer and your peers are quiet.

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Scenarios.Name: Be creative!
Scenarios.Title: Be creative!
Description:
Now you try! What are some feelings that you could have in the moment? These don't have to only be feelings that you've had in the past or negative feelings that you assume you'd have in the moment. Think creatively about both positive and negative feelings that may come up for you in reaction to the situation. If you write a negative feeling, try to also write how you might cope with that feeling. 

Please take 30 seconds to write as many different feelings that you could imagine having in this situation. You can be as creative as you want. If you write any negative feelings (like scared or anxious), try to also write how you could help yourself feel better in the moment.

Scenarios.Name: Be creative!
Scenarios.Title: Be creative!
Description:
Your English teacher calls on you to answer a question about the book you just read. You say your best answer and your peers are quiet.

Feelings in the moment and how you'd handle any negative feelings:
Great job! Now you'll see some behaviors.

Scenarios.Name: Scenario 1 Behaviors
Scenarios.Title: Scenario 1 Behaviors
Words: I think about my answer, smile, and sit back.
I'll review my notes from this book before my test.
I won't answer again in class.
I feel like I should crack a joke so my friends forget about my answer, but don't.
I want to cry, but I take a moment to calm down and focus on the teacher's next question.
Description:
Your English teacher calls on you to answer a question about the book you just read. You say your best answer and your peers are quiet.

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Scenarios.Name: Be creative!
Scenarios.Title: Be creative!
Description:
Your turn! Now it's up to you to write down as many behaviors as you can that might be helpful in the moment. Remember, avoiding or leaving the situation might feel better in the moment, but actually makes anxiety worse in the future! Try to think about behaviors that you can do in the moment that would allow you to stay in the situation. What could you do in the situation that allows you to push through anxiety? 

Please take 30 seconds to write as many behaviors that you could do in the moment that would be helpful and make you feel less anxious in the future.

Scenarios.Name: Be creative!
Scenarios.Title: Be creative!
Description:
Your English teacher calls on you to answer a question about the book you just read. You say your best answer and your peers are quiet.

Behaviors you might do in the moment:

Great job! You've completed the first of three training exercises. Next you'll do the same exercise with a new story. 

Again, the goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.

I'll fail this test, but that doesn't mean I'll fail the class.

Way to go! Now you just have one training exercise left. You're going to practice coming up with thoughts, feelings, and behaviors one more time, and this time the story is going to be from a different topic than the first two you just did. This is to help your brain practice this kind of thinking in lots of different types of situations.

Scenarios.Name: Scenario3
Scenarios.Title: Scenario 3
Description: You go to your grandparents' home for the first time in a while and notice that your grandfather looks a lot less healthy than you remember. No one in your family mentions it.
Scenarios.Caption: Aging grandfather

Scenarios.Name: Scenario 3 Thoughts
Scenarios.Title: Scenario 3 Thoughts
Words: I wonder how my grandfather is feeling.
He's happy to see me.
My grandfather must be dying.
I think about how miserable I would be if he passes away, but then remind myself to enjoy my time with him today.
My family must be keeping a secret about his health, but then tell myself that everyone ages.

Scenarios.Name: Scenario2
Scenarios.Title: Scenario 2
Description: You and your friends are shopping at the mall. You go to the food court and get slushies, and accidentally spill your red slushie down the front of your new white shirt.
Scenarios.Caption: Spilled slushie

Scenarios.Name: Scenario 2 Thoughts
Scenarios.Title: Scenario 2 Thoughts
Words: I think about how this is a common accident.
I think about how it will be a funny story.
I think I will look silly in front of everyone.
I'm annoying to my friends right now, but they will understand that accidents happen.
I'm causing a scene, but the other people here don't know me or care about this situation.

Description:
You go to your grandparents' home for the first time in a while and notice that your grandfather looks a lot less healthy than you remember. No one in your family mentions it. 

Behaviors you might do in the moment:

Great job! You've completed the first of three training exercises. Next you'll do the same exercise with a new story. 

Again, the goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.

I think about how scary the spider looked, but realized how small it really was.

AfterDomain.Name: Quick Thinking
AfterDomain.Title: Quick Thinking
Description:
On the next screen, you'll see a situation that might make someone nervous, worried, scared, or anxious. Here's an example:

You're out with friends and receive this message from your parent saying, "You need to come home right now."

AfterDomain.Name: Quick Thinking
AfterDomain.Title: Quick Thinking
Description:
In the text box, please write as many different thoughts that might come to your mind in that moment. You can add each thought to a new line. You'll have 60 seconds to do this. 

For this example, you might write: 
What did I do wrong? 
 My parent has something really important to tell me. 
 I'm really tired, so I'm glad to be going home. 

The screen will automatically change after 60 seconds.

AfterDomain.Name: Quick Thinking
AfterDomain.Title: Quick Thinking
Description: You don't need to write full sentences, and you should push yourself to write as many different thoughts as possible! These can be a mix of positive and negative thoughts. To add another thought, press the Submit button on your screen.

AfterDomain.Name: Quick Thinking
AfterDomain.Title: Quick Thinking
Description: Your teacher is about to hand back graded tests from last week, and you remember how hard the test was.

AfterDomain.Name: Wrapping Up
AfterDomain.Title: Wrapping Up
Description: Great job practicing flexible thinking today. Remember, try to use your new flexible thinking skills before your next training session!
